title.rendered: Minecraft Java Edition installed in Ubuntu 18.04 from web, Snap or PPA

content.rendered:
In the next article we will look at how Install Minecraft Java Edition on Ubuntu 18.04 in different ways. This is a game that has been talked about on other occasions on this blog. With it we can build houses, find food, fight enemies and much more. This game has multiple game modes. We can play online with friends as well as in single player mode.

minecraft now belongs to Microsoft and is not free. Despite this, it is one of the most popular games in the world. This article will show you how to install it using the package downloaded from the official website. Then we will also see how to install it as a snap package and finally we will see how to install it using the APT package manager.

Installing Minecraft Java Edition on Ubuntu 18.04

Download from the official website

Minecraft is written with Java. Run Minecraft for this reason We must have Java Development Kit (JDK) installed on Ubuntu 18.04 machine. JDK is available in the official Ubuntu 18.04 LTS package repository. Therefore, it can be easily installed.

Before proceeding with the installation, let’s update the APT package repository cache with the following command in the terminal (Ctrl + Alt + T):

sudo apt update

behind, we will install OpenJDK 8 with the following command:

sudo apt install openjdk-8-jdk

After installation we can Check if JDK is working with the following command:

javac -version

Once here we can go to the Official Website page. We should see the next page.

We proceed by clicking on the button Download. It is in the location indicated in the previous screenshot.

Then we will see that we can save or open the compressed file. When we have unzipped this we go to the folder to be created. Inside we find the following files:

To start the program, we must Run the file marked in the previous shot. We may first notice that the following error is returned:

If yes, we will solve it with the following script:

sudo add-apt-repository universe && sudo apt update && sudo apt install -y libgconf-2-4

Run Minecraft Java Edition

This should solve the problem. Now we can restart the .sh file from before:

./minecraft-launcher.sh

If all goes well, you should see the following window.

On the screen that opens in front of us, we can Sign in to Minecraft. If you already have an account, enter your credentials and click Sign In.

If you don’t have an account, just click «Create a new account«. A new registration window will open. Enter your details and click «to register«. We will have to Check the account created by email.

Minecraft is not free. At the time of writing this, A copy of Minecraft costs around €23.95. At the time of writing, if you are just registering and not purchasing the game, You should be able to play a few hours for free. The available hours are communicated to us at the beginning of the game.

The demo version is good enough for users who want to try the game before buying it. If your team can run this game and you like it, then you can decide to buy it.

As you can see, I signed up with a free account. Now we click “play demo”. move forward from the screen, The demo version of the game should be downloadedas you can see in the screenshot below.

Once the download is complete we will see the game start screen.

Minecraft Java Edition should launch after clicking “Play Demo World”.

Minecraft scenario

Installation with the snap package

This game is too available as snap package in Ubuntu 18.04 LTS. We can do this installation from the software option or by running the following command in the terminal (Ctrl + Alt + T):

sudo snap install minecraft

Once the installation is complete, you should be able to launch the game from the Applications menu.

Install using the unofficial PPA

The last of the options to install Minecraft Java Edition that we are going to see is using the APT package manager. We just have to Add the unofficial PPA. To add it, we open a terminal (Ctrl + Alt + T) and run the following command:

sudo add-apt-repository ppa:flexiondotorg/minecraft

The PPA needs to be added and the list of available software updated. Now we can run this command to Install the game:

sudo apt install minecraft-installer

Using the APT package manager should start downloading the Minecraft packages and their dependencies. The game should be installed in a few minutes. Once installed, you should also be able to find it in your Ubuntu 18.04 LTS applications menu.
